Gaming/Final-Fantasy/Flares-and-Bahamut'.title: Flares and Bahamut's Pinnacle
Gaming/Final-Fantasy/Flares-and-Bahamut'.content:
Zettaflare 
                  
                

The strongest Bahamut… no, Final Fantasy spell? Let’s venture into the different versions of Flare throughout Final Fantasy history and the franchise.


Nanoflare

nano - 10-9 - 0.000000001


Nanoflare, used by Ultima Demon in Final Fantasy Tactics. Perhaps a weaker version of Flare.

micro - 10-6 - 0.000001
milli - 10-3 - 0.001
centi - 10-2 - 0.01
deci - 10-1 - 0.1

Flare

Flare, also known as Nuke, is considered an ultimate spell in some of the games (along with Holy, Meteor and Ultima). It can be a non-elemental Black Magic or the final form of the Fire magic.

deca – 101 – 10
kilo – 103 – 1,000
mega – 106 – 1,000,000

Megaflare

Megaflare, performed by Bahamut in Final Fantasy XIII. Also known as Mega Flare, Sun Flare and MegaNuke, and it is usually used by Bahamut - sometimes other versions of it, with different prefixes (Dark Flare by Tiamat).

giga – 109 – 1,000,000,000

Gigaflare

Gigaflare is an upgraded form of Megaflare and just like it, is most often used by Bahamut or very strong bosses.

tera – 1012 – 1,000,000,000,000

Teraflare

Teraflare, also spelled Tera Flare, is an upgraded form of Megaflare even stronger than Gigaflare, and it does colossal non-elemental damage to all targets. It is universally exclusive to Bahamut and incarnations of his, and was the spell used in the ending of FF XIV.

peta – 1015 – 1,000,000,000,000,000
exa – 1018 – 1,000,000,000,000,000,000

Exaflare

Exaflare is an ability associated with variants of Bahamut, but not Bahamut himself. Based on the spell’s name etymology, one can expect it to be stronger than Teraflare.

zetta -1021 – 1,000,000,000,000,000,000,000

Zettaflare

Zettaflare stands at the pinnacle of abilities not only in Final Fantasy, but the entire Square Enix multiverse.
Let us put this into perspective. “Teraflare” is what Bahamut used to wipe out the original FF14 universe and “Zettaflare” trascends that benchmark by two tiers.
An actual canon estimation of the strength of this spell is one QUADRILLION times “Teraflare”‘s power.
This is the most destructive spell in the franchise, capable of wiping out entire universes.
It is so powerful that it cannot be used under normal circumstances and prior to this game (Final Fantasy XVI), there have only ever been two characters in all of Square Enix who were able to cast it, making it extremely limited.
The first one was Airy from Bravely Default who could only use it after being powered up by an Eldritch God who, at that point, had already devoured several thousand alternate universes to obtain that level of power.
The second was Donald Duck from Kingdom Hearts 3, making Bahamut the official third.
Here in Bahamut’s case, he used it only after absorbing a crystal that has been storing several thousand years worth of aether in it. Donald is the only exception to the special circumstances requisite.
The spell has existed in the the series for a while now but was treated like an myth, something nobody thought possible to achieve until now. The fact that this is the first time it’s been ever been used in Final Fantasy is outstanding.

Gaming/TFT/Set-16/TFT-Set-16---Bard-meta.title: TFT Set 16 - Bard meta
Gaming/TFT/Set-16/TFT-Set-16---Bard-meta.content:
Bard’s Caretaker trait is very powerful.


                  
                  Caretaker 
                  
                

After winning player combat, gain a random unit from Runeterra. After losing combat, gain free rerolls, with the amount increasing by stage.


Take an Economy augment and roll for Bard more than 80% of your games.
Why? The rerolls on losses more than make up for the early economy you lose, especially in stage 4. Greed and stack Bard rolls until you finish your level 8 or are at 2 lives remaining.
Works in every comp, but here are some specific examples below.
Caitlyn 3 T-Hex
Bard often summons a Caitlyn when you win and rolls help you star up units to unlock T-Hex.
Greed Bard until 2 lives and swap out him and 6 Piltover for legendaries.

Draven Skarner fast 9
Use free Bard rolls to hit Draven 2 on 3-5 level 7 and greed Bard further to hit 4 cost upgrades and go 9 and swap to Kindred carry.

Diana Shurima
Use bard rolls to hit Leona 2 and then greed him and stack rolls in stage 4 to complete board.


You seriously can play him towards any comp with an econ augment or high econ start.
The units you roll for on stage 2 with bard is usually Econ Ionia, 3 Ixtal, 3 Bilgewater, or tempo.
If low hp roll on 3-5, if high HP can roll lvl 8.

Credits to AesahTFT’s post.

Gaming/TFT/Set-16/TFT-Set-16---Swain-Pos.title: TFT Set 16 - Swain Positioning
Gaming/TFT/Set-16/TFT-Set-16---Swain-Pos.content:
Swain is one of the most splashable units of this set, be it for his traits (Arcanist giving AP to the entire board, Juggernaut makes him more reliably durable and Noxus can be a good addition, especially with Bronze for Life) or for his AoE CC.
Let us look at his ability: he summons his eye within 2 hexes. The eye is the center of the stun and targets the largest clump of champions in a 3 hex radius.
Playing Swain
Swain can be defaulted in the middle as he can reach both corners, rendering it an easy way to catch opponents who have not prepared against it.
Playing against Swain
If the enemy has prepared for it, they can avoid Swain’s stun no matter what. Against Swain, all you have to do is make sure your ranged carry is not in the largest clump of champions on the board.


Credits to AesahTFT’s post.

Notes/Projectors/Keystone-Correction.title: Keystone correction
Notes/Projectors/Keystone-Correction.content:
When a projector is placed at an angle to the screen, the projected image becomes distorted into a trapezoid shape instead of a rectangle.
This distortion is called keystone effect.
Keystone correction is the method of adjusting the image so it appears rectangular again.
There are several types of keystone correction.
Types of Keystone Correction
Vertical Keystone
Vertical keystone correction fixes distortion when the projector is too high (ceiling mounted) or too low (table placement) relative to the screen.
Horizontal Keystone
Horizontal keystone correction fixes distortion when the projector is placed to the left or right of the screen’s center.
4-Point (Corner) Keystone
4-point keystone allows adjustment of each corner of the image independently. This makes it possible to correct both vertical and horizontal distortions at once and adapt to uneven projection surfaces.
Auto Keystone
Auto keystone uses sensors to detect the angle of the projector and automatically corrects the distortion.
Lens Shift (Optical Alternative)
Lens shift is not digital correction but a mechanical adjustment that moves the lens up/down or left/right to align the image.
Because it is optical, there is no scaling and no loss in image quality. It is available mainly in higher-end projectors.

Notes/Projectors/Lens-shift-function.title: Lens-shift function
Notes/Projectors/Lens-shift-function.content:
Lens shift is a mechanical adjustment in a projector that moves the lens inside the projector housing. By shifting the lens up, down, left, or right, the image position on the screen can be changed without tilting the projector and without introducing trapezoid distortion.
Unlike digital keystone correction, lens shift preserves the full resolution and image quality because no digital scaling is applied.
Types of Lens Shift
Vertical Lens Shift
Vertical lens shift moves the image up or down on the screen.
Horizontal Lens Shift
Horizontal lens shift moves the image left or right. Usually offers a smaller adjustment range than vertical shift.
Combined (Vertical + Horizontal)
Some projectors provide both vertical and horizontal lens shift. This combination gives maximum flexibility, allowing placement above, below, or to the side of screen center without compromising image quality.

Notes/Projectors/Projector-light-sources.title: Projector light sources
Notes/Projectors/Projector-light-sources.content:
Projector light sources fall into two broad families: traditional lamp-based sources and solid-state sources.
Lamp-based sources use a replaceable bulb that produces light through electric discharge in a gas and metal salts.
Solid-state sources use semiconductor devices such as LEDs or lasers to create light without a conventional bulb.
Types of light sources
Lamp-based
Lamp-based projectors typically require a warm-up period to reach stable brightness and they lose brightness gradually as the lamp ages. Lamps have a limited rated life, often between 2,000 and 5,000 hours in average consumer and business models, and sometimes more with eco modes. Lamp replacement is a recurring maintenance cost and proper disposal is necessary because some lamps contain mercury or other hazardous materials.
Lamp-based systems are the oldest and were the standard for many years. The common variants are Ultra High Performance (UHP) lamps, metal halide, and xenon arc lamps.
UHP and metal halide lamps deliver high peak brightness and have been widely used in consumer, education, and business projectors.
Xenon arc lamps, which are rarer in small projectors, have been common in cinema projectors and in specialized high-color-accuracy applications.
LED
LED projectors use arrays of high-power LEDs as the light source. LEDs provide very long operating life compared to lamps and maintain color stability over time. They reach usable brightness instantly and support instant on/off operation without warm-up. LED-based projectors are compact and energy efficient, and they produce less heat.
The main limitation for LED projectors has historically been maximum brightness. Consumer and portable LED projectors are excellent for small- to medium-size screens and for dark to moderately lit rooms, but they struggle in very bright environments unless paired with a smaller screen or very close throw distances. LEDs typically advertise lifespans in the tens of thousands of hours, commonly 20,000 to 30,000 hours for many models.
Laser
Laser sources are solid-state, with long rated lifetimes often quoted in the tens of thousands of hours, and they provide near-instant on/off capability, minimal drift in color and brightness, and lower maintenance because there is no replaceable bulb. Lasers can achieve much higher lumen outputs than LED, making them ideal for bright-room and large-screen applications.
Laser projectors come in multiple flavors:
Direct RGB laser
RGB laser projectors use separate red, green, and blue laser emitters to generate light directly. These systems offer the best color gamut and can reach very high brightness.
Blue laser with phosphor
Blue-laser plus phosphor systems use blue lasers to excite a phosphor wheel that emits yellow light which, combined with the remaining blue, creates full-color images. This approach scales well to very high brightness levels and is common in large venue and cinema-class projectors.
Laser-phosphor
Laser-phosphor is technically a hybrid in the sense that a laser pumps a phosphor to create broad-spectrum white light that is then used by the projector engine.

Notes/Projectors/Throw-correction.title: Throw correction
Notes/Projectors/Throw-correction.content:
Throw correction refers to a projector’s ability to adjust the image size and placement relative to the distance between the projector and the screen, without having to physically move the projector.
It is closely related to the concept of throw ratio, which defines how wide the image will be at a given distance.
Throw correction is usually achieved with a zoom lens or variable optics that allow users to fine-tune the image size. Some projectors are designed with short throw or ultra-short throw lenses to project large images from very close distances.
The flexibility of throw correction directly affects installation options in different environments.
Types of Throw Correction
Optical Zoom (Variable Throw)
An optical zoom lens allows the image size to be increased or decreased by adjusting the lens, without moving the projector. The zoom range is expressed as a ratio (e.g. 1.2x, 1.6x).
Fixed Throw (No Zoom)
Some projectors, especially budget models and portable units, have a fixed throw ratio with no zoom adjustment. The only way to change image size is by moving the projector closer or farther from the screen.
Short Throw
Short throw projectors have specially designed lenses that project large images from a short distance (e.g. 100-inch image from 1–2 meters).
Ultra-Short Throw (UST)
Ultra-short throw projectors can sit just a few centimeters from the wall or screen and still project very large images.

Recipes/Ragù-alla-bolognese.title: Ragù alla bolognese
Recipes/Ragù-alla-bolognese.content:
One of the simplest, most flavourful ragù you can make.
Preferred pasta to use is tagliatelle, but spaghetti is what made it so commonly known internationally.
Recipe


                  
                  Ingredients 
                  
                


Olive oil
150g of bacon
300g of minced beef
300g of passata di pomodoro
Celery
Onion
Carrot
Red wine
1l vegetable broth
Optional: Dark chocolate



Pour olive oil in a big pot on high heat. Drop the cubed bacon in, after a few minutes drop the chopped celery, onion and carrot in and let it brown. After a few minutes again, drop the minced beef.
Scorch, then deglaze using wine.
The color of the ragù should be brown, not red.
After that, pour all of the passata di pomodoro and start cooking for 2 hours on low-medium heat, while constantly checking how much liquid is inside and refilling with a ladle of vegetable broth around every 20 minutes.
You can optionally add dark chocolate to make the flavour profile richer and add a slight bit of creaminess.
When sauce has thickened, taste: if necessary, add a glass of milk, then salt and pepper.

Roadmap-for-learning-the-Hungarian-langu.title: Roadmap for learning the Hungarian language
Roadmap-for-learning-the-Hungarian-langu.content:
As some of you might know, my girlfriend is Hungarian. As a pet project of mine, I wish to learn Hungarian in order to not only learn more about the culture of my loved one, but also to conversate with her family more easily. Also, it will help me when I go visit Budapest again.
Learning a language unfortunately is not that easy though. In my opinion, apps like Duolingo don’t really help as much as they’re advertised to. For this reason, we are going to take a slightly different approach. While I learned English and German simply by being exposed to the languages, and Italian because it is my native tongue, for Hungarian we will use multiple tools.
First, research has pointed me to many different resources.
Resources

Hungarian Alphabet with Pronunciation
Videos for Consonants, Vowels and Spelling Rules
Hungarian Numbers

These will be the three primary initial resources we will use in order to build strong fundamentals. They are all taken from this article on how to learn Hungarian.
We will combine videos with any AI capable of watching them in order to transcribe everything that has been said.
Our primary AI used will be ChatGPT, with the creation of a Project just for learning Hungarian.
In order to properly understand the pronunciation of the words, the LLM will be used in order to write a phonetical spelling as it would be said in Italian.
Roadmap, Step by Step

Hungarian Alphabet and Pronunciation
Understand Agglutination, the Nature of the Language
Understand the Hungarian Word Order
Numbers
Common Vocabulary
Immerse Yourself

Software/Atomic-Design.title: Atomic design
Software/Atomic-Design.content:
Atomic design is a methodology composed of five distinct stages working together to create interface design systems in a more deliberate and hierarchical manner.
The five stages of atomic design are:

Atoms
Molecules
Organisms
Templates
Pages

Atomic design is not a linear process, but rather a mental model to help us think of our user interfaces as both a cohesive whole and a collection of parts at the same time. Each of the five stages plays a key role in the hierarchy of our interface design systems.
Atoms
If atoms are the basic building blocks of matter, then the atoms of our interfaces serve as the foundational building blocks that comprise all our user interfaces.
These atoms include basic HTML elements like form labels, inputs, buttons, and others that can’t be broken down any further without ceasing to be functional.
Molecules
In interfaces, molecules are relatively simple groups of UI elements functioning together as a unit. For example, a form label, search input, and button can join together to create a search form molecule.
Organisms
Organisms are relatively complex UI components composed of groups of molecules and/or atoms and/or other organisms. These organisms form distinct sections of an interface.
This header organism is composed of a search form molecule, logo atom, and primary navigation molecule.
Templates
Templates are page-level objects that place components into a layout and articulate the design’s underlying content structure. To build on our previous example, we can take the header organism and apply it to a homepage template.
Another important characteristic of templates is that they focus on the page’s underlying content structure rather than the page’s final content. Design systems must account for the dynamic nature of content, so it’s very helpful to articulate important properties of components like image sizes and character lengths for headings and text passages.
Pages
Pages are specific instances of templates that show what a UI looks like with real representative content in place. Building on our previous example, we can take the homepage template and pour representative text, images, and media into the template to show real content in action.
The page stage replaces placeholder content with real representative content to bring the design system to life.
In addition to demonstrating the final interface as your users will see it, pages are essential for testing the effectiveness of the underlying design system. It is at the page stage that we’re able to take a look at how all those patterns hold up when real content is applied to the design system.
Pages also provide a place to articulate variations in templates, which is crucial for establishing robust and reliant design systems.
TL;DR:

Atoms are UI elements that can’t be broken down any further and serve as the elemental building blocks of an interface.
Molecules are collections of atoms that form relatively simple UI components.
Organisms are relatively complex components that form discrete sections of an interface.
Templates place components within a layout and demonstrate the design’s underlying content structure.
Pages apply real content to templates and articulate variations to demonstrate the final UI and test the resilience of the design system.

Software/Screaming-Architecture.title: Screaming Architecture
Software/Screaming-Architecture.content:
Screaming Architecture is a concept introduced by renowned software developer and thought leader Robert C. Martin, often referred to as “Uncle Bob”.
As the name suggests, it is a principle in software design focusing on making the features of your system the primary concern of your architecture. Your software architecture should “scream” its intent and purpose.
Why “Screaming” Architecture?
The idea is that the structure of your codebase should immediately convey its business purpose. This goes against traditional architectures, as they emphasize the technical aspect of it. Uncle Bob illustrated this with an analogy: if you walk up to a building and see its architecture, you can often tell whether it is a library, school or office instantly. The same should apply to your architecture.
Business & Domain Logic
In many projects, the file structures can be like this:
controllers/
services/
repositories/
models/

This structure describes technical roles and tells you that the system uses MVC (Model-View-Controller), but it doesn’t tell you how it handles financial data, user management or content creation.
Here is an example of a structure that “screams” its intent using domain-driven principles:
/src
    /accounting
        Ledger.cs
        Transaction.cs
        Account.cs
        TaxService.cs
    /sales
        Order.cs
        Invoice.cs
        Customer.cs
        DiscountPolicy.cs

or:
/src
    /orders
        OrderController.cs
        OrderService.cs
        OrderRepository.cs
        Order.cs
        OrderItem.cs
    /inventory
        InventoryController.cs
        InventoryService.cs
        InventoryRepository.cs
        InventoryItem.cs
